content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text:
Bethel had gone big. The common room was shaped like an egg, with the domed ceiling forty feet high. An ornate chandelier hung down and gave the whole place a warm light, which was supplemented by a fireplace off to one side. Bethel was mostly past feeling discomfort from being able to reshape herself, and was indulging in a flair for the dramatic, which went like a streak through the whole house. What she couldn't produce as simply a piece of house from the Anyhouse ability, she was pulling from Earth via the backpack's ability. As Valencia put it, we lived in an enormous house where every single room was a Room of Requirement.

At times, I regretted giving her the Harry Potter books. I hadn't thought that she would glom onto them as much as she did; she had read through the series and then decided that there wasn't much more that the world of literature could offer her, in spite of my suggestions for other series she could try.

On hearing Valencia's announcement, Amaryllis set down her papers and stared. She had a desk in the common room; she was working far, far harder than the rest of us, and if not for the desk, probably wouldn't have spent as much time in our company.

content.speaker: Valencia
content.text: It is incredibly unprofessional for him to ask you on a date,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Amaryllis.

content.speaker: Valencia
content.text: Well I was the one to ask him,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Valencia.

content.speaker: Valencia
content.text: Because I knew that he wouldn't have asked me on his own.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: Oh,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Amaryllis. She was frowning.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: It's still incredibly unprofessional for him to accept.

content.speaker: Solace
content.text: I think it's nice,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Solace.

content.speaker: Solace
content.text: He seems like a very safe choice for you to experiment with courtship.

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: She was sitting on the floor, putting together a jigsaw puzzle. Her body was that of an adolescent crantek, which developmentally equated to about a five year old human. The puzzle was a way of developing visual pattern recognition and fine motor control, both of which still needed some development.

content.speaker: Valencia
content.text: Thank you, Solace,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Valencia. She looked to Amaryllis.

content.speaker: Valencia
content.text: I didn't say it because I wanted anyone to weigh in, I said it because I wanted to share something important that was happening in my life.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: Did you ask him with a devil's skills at manipulation?

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text:
asked Amaryllis.

Valencia shifted in her seat.

content.speaker: Valencia
content.text: No,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: she said.

content.speaker: Fenn
content.text: That really wasn't a convincing no,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Fenn. She laid with her head in my lap, reading through the first Harry Potter book, with the grey cat on her lap. She was only reading at Valencia's insistence and a bit of annoyance at not being able to follow what she was saying half the time. I had been relaxing, listening to music and not thinking of anything much. Most of the music we had was vinyl, and I was doing some cultural exploration of Earth of my own, since almost all of it was before my time. We were currently listening to jazz, which was Grak's choice; improvisational music was apparently a mainstay of dwarven culture, though theirs was (to hear him tell it) much more constrained, or at least had been within his one specific clan.

content.speaker: Valencia
content.text: I took in a devil to see what I would say,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Valencia.

content.speaker: Valencia
content.text: And then a few more to get second opinions. But when I asked him, it was just me, with my own words. They were only giving advice.

content.speaker: Fenn
content.text: Seems sketchy,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text:
said Fenn.

Valencia crossed her arms.

content.speaker: Valencia
content.text: I didn't want to screw it up.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: There are things that he can't know,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Amaryllis.

content.speaker: Valencia
content.text: I know,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text:
said Valencia.

The List of Things That People Can't Know

1.  Game layer
2.  The identity of Amaryllis Penndraig
3.  Our possession of a teleportation key
4.  The assault at Aumann's
5.  The existence of the locus
6.  The public fight in Boastre Vino
7.  The murder of Larkspur and company
8.  Releasing Fallatehr from prison
9.  Valencia the non-anima
10. Extracting Esuen
11. The hijacking of the Down and Out
12. Our "possession" of a meta-entad
13. Our deal with Uniquities

Jorge already knew a whole lot of those, naturally, since he was Finch's second-in-command, a relatively high-ranking member of Uniquities, and part of the operation that had briefly captured Valencia. The ones he didn't know were of concern, and the one Valencia was at the greatest danger of revealing to him was the identity of her father, which would raise a whole lot of really obvious questions that we didn't want to answer.

content.speaker: Grak
content.text: What do you two talk about?

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: asked Grak.

content.speaker: Fenn
content.text: Harry Potter,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Fenn.

content.speaker: Valencia
content.text: We talk about other things,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Valencia, slightly defensive. She looked at the book Fenn was halfway through.

content.speaker: Valencia
content.text: It's good, isn't it?

content.speaker: Fenn
content.text: It is,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Fenn.

content.speaker: Fenn
content.text: Though some things get lost in translation, and some of it I'm sure Amaryllis would rail against as being bigotry.

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: She leafed back a handful of pages.

content.speaker: Fenn
content.text: Greedy goblins, for example.

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I nodded at that. "I mean, their primary cultural trait on Aerb is still material possession, right?"

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: You have to make a distinction between the traits of a culture and a species,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Amaryllis.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: You don't say that goblins are greedy, you don't say that goblins focus on possession of written information, you instead say that historically their society has been dominated by warring gold mages and a veneration of wealth, and that currently, the Kel'e'thar Library engages in some practices which, yes, might contain some elements of greed.

content.speaker: Fenn
content.text: Jesus that's a mouthful,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Fenn.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: Don't take the Lord's name in vain,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Amaryllis, almost by reflex. They did that a lot, enough that the others had joined in. I wasn't too big a fan; I'd been raised Christian, and while I was an atheist, it sort of seemed like they were mocking a religion that they only had second-hand knowledge of. Granted, Amaryllis had read the Bible, and Fenn had read at least part of it so they could talk about it, but it still felt kind of ...disrespectful, I guess, even if it was disrespect toward a religion that I didn't have a lot of respect towards.

content.speaker: Valencia
content.text: I like Mrs. Rowling's goblins better than Juniper's,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Valencia.

content.speaker: Valencia
content.text: No offense, Juniper.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: I'd really hesitate to call them mine,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I said.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: Everything on Aerb is kind of … twisted, warped, different in different ways, and some of it was just me being silly or making jokes.

content.speaker: Fenn
content.text: Yeah, Aerb goblins suck,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Fenn.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: Please never say anything like that in public,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Amaryllis.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: You're a government official now.

content.speaker: Fenn
content.text: I shall continue to hide and vote how you tell me to vote,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Fenn.

content.speaker: Fenn
content.text: And I'll wait for the next proper adventure we all know is coming.

content.speaker: Grak
content.text: I itch to have something to do,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Grak. He glanced down at his wooden hand. It hadn't seen combat yet. There were a few gnarls and knots in it, but it was tough as iron, with a few extra properties as well. I might have cut off my own hand, if I had thought that the locus would assent to that. (The locus was the only one not in the common room. Bethel was the common room, but wasn't presenting an illusion; she only appeared when she wanted to talk, or when someone called for her.)

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: After the first round of tuunglings is born, we'll have some time to breathe,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Amaryllis.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: My engineers are already hard at work, not entirely autonomous at this point, but close enough that I could leave them for a week.

content.speaker: Fenn
content.text: Maybe I'll stay back this time,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Fenn.

content.speaker: Fenn
content.text: Catch some sun, watch some anime, not get shot at or cut in half, that kind of thing.

content.speaker: Grak
content.text: My hand was cut off,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Grak.

content.speaker: Grak
content.text: I did not complain.

content.speaker: Valencia
content.text: If my hand was cut off it would be gone forever,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Valencia.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: Technically we could ice it and then use surgery to reattach, along with Earth antibiotics and medicines in order to ensure that it would heal properly,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Amaryllis.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: But you'd be out of action for a very long time, even if the surgery was successful.

content.speaker: Fenn
content.text: Wouldn't you just use some ninjutsu to dodge the attack?

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: asked Fenn.

content.speaker: Valencia
content.text: Not all fights are possible to win without getting hurt,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Valencia.

content.speaker: Fenn
content.text: Well, you've been kicking my fucking ass when we spar, I'll give you that,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text:
said Fenn.

I'd seen a few of those beat-downs happen in our gym. Fenn was faster and stronger, with elf luck on her side, but Valencia was a far, far better fighter. It was a little unfair to Fenn, because archery was her personal domain of excellence, but Fenn had pretty much every other advantage there was to have, including height, reach, and (barely) weight. Fenn hadn't won once, though she was improving. (Maybe this is patronizing, but I was really proud of Fenn for sticking it out. She had a bit of a tendency to bail out on things she wasn't good at, which I figured was probably a response to the elven cultural demand of perfection.)

content.speaker: Grak
content.text: I would vote for Glassy Fields,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Grak.

content.speaker: Valencia
content.text: No more votes,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Valencia, folding her arms.

content.speaker: Fenn
content.text: Can't we rest on our laurels?

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: asked Fenn.

content.speaker: Fenn
content.text: Besides, we haven't even gotten our campaign of Arches back up and running.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: We've been resting on our laurels,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I replied. She looked up from my lap with a frown.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: It's true. Amaryllis has been the only one actually doing much work.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: There's enough work for whoever wants it,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Amaryllis.

content.speaker: Solace
content.text: I've been tending to the locus and attempting to restore my connection to the flowers of my garden,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Solace as she placed a puzzle piece.

content.speaker: Solace
content.text: I do think that I deserve a bit of rest.

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: She looked up at me, briefly.

content.speaker: Solace
content.text: Were we comparing things that we hadn't complained about? I did die, after all.

content.speaker: Fenn
content.text: Well, you did get better,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text:
said Fenn.

I sighed.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: I didn't mean to say that we didn't deserve a break, or that the relative downtime --

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text:
Amaryllis gave a short little laugh.

"-- for some of us wasn't deserved or necessary, especially with the months in the time chamber stacked up like they were, nor did I mean to devalue the work that people were doing, but ... with Bethel here, it would be easy to simply abandon our higher objectives and settle into the lap of luxury. I don't want to do that." As soon as I said that, a small part of me said, 'actually, I kind of do want to do that'.

"I'm happy for the lap I'm in," said Fenn. She reached down to pet the cat that was curled up on her. "There's something to be said for laps."

"The Dungeon Master will punish idleness," said Grak.

"I came out of eight months of almost pure idleness entirely unscathed," said Amaryllis. She'd returned partial attention to her work. "I'm starting to trust Juniper's interpretation of the Dungeon Master's views."

"There have got to be limits," I said. "I mean, unless this is going to turn into a totally different game, which I guess is possible, it's really hard to do tabletop games where the game is just managing an estate, or a kingdom, or whatever. The game system isn't set up for massed combat, so all scenarios where there would be massed combat get abstracted out, and the actual play slash narrative is really about this small, plucky band of adventurers doing the things that small bands of people can realistically do." I paused. "That was always how I'd done it anyway." The truth was, I was gaining distance from Earth. The memories didn't come as freely as they had back when I'd first arrived on Aerb.

It was hard to reconcile Uther and Arthur, but when I tried, that was always what I came back to. A teenager from Earth, immersed in this other world, with no one and nothing from home but the things he could bring forward from his memories. He spent his entire adult life on Aerb. My working theory was that he wasn't obsessed with Tiff, making drawings of her because of a long-ago love that had never faded. Instead, she was nostalgia incarnate, a memory so old that it might have been a dream. He'd drawn her to say to himself that yes, there really had been such a place as Earth, it hadn't all been a vivid dream. But Uther had lived his life at full tilt, always one adventure after another, even during the time he was founding his empire, so the years wouldn't have felt like years, they'd have felt like decades, more distance ... and he'd have felt a keening for his childhood, which happened in that faraway, ephemeral place called Earth. That was also my working theory for what Uther was looking for down the Boundless Pit: home.

None of that excused what he'd done with Bethel. Maybe none of that was even true. It made me sick to think about, and sympathetic toward Arthur and the pain he'd felt, and frustrated with the lack of answers about what had happened to him. I didn't really know who he had been.

"Well I'd rather not have an adventure just for the sake of it," said Fenn. "But speaking of adventures for the sake of it, can we finally play Arches? We're all here, we've got nothing better to do, I've had my campaign ready for ages, and I know that Juniper's got stuff ready if we want to play his. Mary?"

"I ... yes," said Amaryllis. She began sorting some papers. "Give me a minute to file things away, I can spare two or three hours."

"Well, that's the hard one," said Fenn. "Grak?"

"Yes," he said. "Juniper's? Or yours?"

"Actually," I said. "Bethel and Val have never played a roleplaying game before, so I was thinking that maybe we would start with something fast and easy that we can get through quickly?" I bent down and gave Fenn a kiss. "Come on, up."

She mumbled something about 'cozy', despite being the one that wanted to get a game going, and eventually got up so we could get to the big table, where we ate most of our meals. With Bethel in full control of the backpack's powers, hot food appeared on plates right in front of us, exactly to order. Valencia, as had become typical, said that this was exactly like the Great Hall at Hogwarts. For our impromptu game night, there were cans of pop and bags of chips.

"A new game?" asked Solace as she sat down at the table. She had a booster on her chair, so she could rest her arms on the table. "I rather liked Arches."

"Arches is rules-light, but it's not that rules-light," I said, as I watched everyone gather. "Bethel?" I asked the room.

She appeared in her customary seat at the table, which was as illusory as her physical form. "I'm listening," she said.

"Always listening," muttered Fenn.

"I don't particularly care if you have sex," said Bethel. "Hundreds of people have had sex in my rooms."

"Well, I care," said Fenn.

"Do you?" asked Solace. "I seem to recall you being quite free with your love."

"They were," said Amaryllis. She took her seat next to Solace.

"If people know, it's -- whatever," said Fenn. "I'm not going to feel ashamed about that. But someone actively watching feels too much like a third person in there with us. I'm not into it." She looked at me.

"I understand," I said. I didn't agree, but I did understand. The locus could (probably) see everything in its domain, but apparently that didn't trip the same internal reaction in Fenn. I thought it was probably just the fact that it was Bethel that got to Fenn. Our newly-acquired house was perfect, imperious, and powerful, much like the elves that had judged her unworthy when she was growing up.

"You were saying about a different game?" asked Valencia.

"Yeah," I said. "Arches is light on rules, but it's on the heavy end of light, if that makes sense. I was thinking that we could warm up with something that's single stat, single die, what they used to call a one-page game. There are a couple to choose from, ones I know well enough that I shouldn't need a refresher, and Bethel should be able to snag the rules. In Honey Heist you're all different bears and you've got two stats, Bear and Criminal that you use for everything, um, Lasers and Feelings probably doesn't translate, since it's a Star Trek pastiche, and the same probably goes for Actual Cannibal Shia LaBeouf, which --"

"Stop," said Amaryllis. Her voice was sharp. "No one speak."

"Wha --" began Fenn.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: No, stop. No one say another fucking word,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Amaryllis. Her eyes were wide.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: Infohazard. Don't speak without thinking about every single word coming out of your mouth, no nouns, keep yourself to the most common hundred words in Anglish.

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: She got up from her chair.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: We need to go to war footing, there's a sixty percent chance that most of us will be dead in the next hour, start getting armored up, now. Quickly.

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: Fenn looked like she was about to say something, but she glanced at Valencia, who had risen from her own chair and adopted a stance that was familiar from the sparring they'd done together. Whatever Fenn had wanted to say, she thought better of it and began disgorging armor and weapons from the glove. I had practiced getting armored quickly, but it still took some time. Most of us will be dead in the next hour. I tried to think about what I had said and give some context to the threat we were suddenly facing.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: Barriers won't work,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Amaryllis as she put on the immobility plate. She was speaking fast, almost breathless.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: Wards won't work. Obstructions won't work, raw killing power won't work, magic will be shrugged off or only partially successful, no known entad can stop him, and he scales to any threats. On the first invocation of the word there's a sixty percent chance he'll appear, and if he does we're absolutely fucked -- no Juniper, don't write anything down.

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I had a pencil in my hand and dropped it at her command.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: Can … I … think?

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I asked, measuring each word carefully. Can I think the name that has you spooked? I was continuing to do up the straps on my armor. Shia LaBeouf. Shit.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: Think all you want,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Amaryllis.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: Maintain protocol for speech, no writing whatsoever.

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: She was sweating slightly, maybe from the exertion of rapidly donning full plate armor. Valencia, wearing a dress but without armor of her own, helped to do up the immobility plate.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: Sixty percent he comes, forty percent he doesn't,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Amaryllis as her helmet came down to cover her face.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: I'll explain after, if I can.

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I was pretty sure that I already knew what was going on.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: You've come up to Craig's cabin for the weekend, prepared for a night of gaming, but not knowing the horrible fate that awaits you,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I said. We were at Arthur's house on Halloween night, too old for trick-or-treating. We'd each brought a bag of fun-sized candy, which were strewn across the table. The lights were off for this part of the evening, leaving us to play by candlelight.

content.speaker: Craig
content.text: Spooky,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Craig with a roll of his eyes.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: It is spooky,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I said.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: There have been little things, little signs, the old man who issued you a word of warning at the gas station, a blood-smeared sign you passed by on the dirt road, which you told yourselves was just roadkill, the sound the radio made when you turned it on that seemed very much like a pained scream before the radio shorted out.

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I had prepared that ahead of time.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: But you've almost managed to forget all the foreboding and have settled in for a night enjoying each other's company. The fireplace crackles beside you. Suddenly, your idle conversation is interrupted when one of the windows rattles,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I said.

content.speaker: Tiff
content.text: Must have been the wind?

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: asked Tiff.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: Might have been,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I replied with a small smile.

content.speaker: Arthur
content.text: Anyway, as I was saying,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Arthur,

content.speaker: Arthur
content.text: My father got me this neat book full of Aramaic, and I was going to try to read some of it.

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: He was putting on a bit of a character voice, a little higher, a little more nasal, classically nerdy.

content.speaker: Reimer
content.text: Can I be armed?

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: asked Reimer.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: Wouldn't do you any good,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I replied.

content.speaker: Reimer
content.text: Really?

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: asked Reimer.

content.speaker: Tiff
content.text: Just get into the genre, Reimer,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Tiff.

content.speaker: Tiff
content.text: Horror movie rules. A gun is never enough, he's supernatural. You go to a phone, the line is dead. You reach a policeman sitting in his car, you're going to discover that his throat has been slit.

content.speaker: Arthur
content.text: Wait,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Arthur.

content.speaker: Arthur
content.text: Forget the book of Aramaic, I'm going to the bathroom.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: The bathroom?

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I asked.

content.speaker: Arthur
content.text: We're away from civilization in a run-down cabin,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Arthur.

content.speaker: Arthur
content.text: It's a dark and stormy night.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: Sure,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I said. I hadn't described the weather, or even given all that much detail to the cabin.

content.speaker: Arthur
content.text: I want to start this right,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Arthur.

content.speaker: Arthur
content.text: I stand in front of the mirror, I close my eyes. I say it slowly, getting faster each time. Shia LaBeouf, Shia LaBeouf, Shia LaBeouf! Does anything happen?

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: You open your eyes?

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I asked.

content.speaker: Arthur
content.text: I do,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: Arthur smiled.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: He's standing behind you, fully naked, his beard drenched in blood,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text:
I said.

An hour into waiting, Amaryllis decided that it was time for her to talk.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: We don't know if it's a name, or just a word,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Amaryllis.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: Joon? Name or word?

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: Name,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I said, saying as little as possible.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: If you invoke it, a man shows up,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Amaryllis.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: Not all the time. Sixty percent, maybe.

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: She let out a shaky breath.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: If you invoke it three times, you guarantee his arrival.

content.speaker: Grak
content.text: And then?

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: asked Grak, his words as carefully measured as mine had been.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: He starts killing,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Amaryllis.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: Sometimes dozens, sometimes hundreds. It depends on who's around. He's arbitrarily strong. He moves as fast as he needs to. Anything you put in front of him, he'll grow a new power to tear down or go around.

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: She let out a breath.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: I think if he were coming, he would have. We can stand down.

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: She sat in her chair and slumped against it. I returned to my seat as well, still in my armor and not feeling any relief.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: To be clear,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I said slowly.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: It was the name after --

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: No,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Amaryllis.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: Don't repeat anything. I'll do it. You said 'actual' then 'cannibal' and then the name. Don't speak it, don't spell it, don't write it, don't try putting it in code, don't knowingly transmit it to anyone else, in whole or in part, through any medium or any level of cryptography.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: Okay,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I said, swallowing.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: How much of that is,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I tried to think of a simple word,

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: too much caution?

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I was pretty sure it was only the name we needed to worry about, and using simple language to speak was just paranoia and a reminder to think very carefully about every single word spoken.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: None of it is paranoia,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Amaryllis.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: We've tried to harness him in the past. It always ends with everyone dying.

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I frowned, trying to think about that.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: If you were able to transmit it to someone, somehow,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I said.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: Have them say it, weaponize it? Suicide bombers?

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I was relaxing the attention I was paying to my words, just a hitch. Obviously in the long-term, I couldn't be so careful that I had to think over every word out of my mouth, especially if there was only a single name that I really had to watch out for, and that name was as uncommon as Shia LaBeouf.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: Your suicidal agent would die,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Amaryllis.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: Any means of protecting them or bringing them back would fail. Then he would go after whoever told the agent the word, and whoever gave the order, even if they didn't know the word. Five of my cousins died in that particular experiment. It's not something that anyone can actually use, except as an absolute last resort when all you want to do is call down extreme violence on yourself and everyone else in the area.

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I narrowed my eyes slightly at that. She could have killed Fallatehr with it, when she'd been captured by him, just before he'd touched her soul. Shia LaBeouf would have killed her, but he'd also have killed Fallatehr too. Understanding dawned on me as I thought back to what she'd said about that misadventure. 'Suicide comes in many flavors', she'd said.

content.speaker: Fenn
content.text: Is Joon in danger now?

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: asked Fenn.

content.speaker: Fenn
content.text: If any of us say it, this thing will kill him too, even if he's nowhere close?

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: Yes,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Amaryllis.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: Fuck,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I said.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: I heard it from a phonograph playing in the middle of nowhere on a loop, recorded by a dead man who had heard it from others who were also dead,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Amaryllis.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: That's the only safe way to learn it.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: Wait,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I said.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: Writing triggers it?

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: Amaryllis nodded.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: We have to stop using the backpack. We can't pull movies from out of it, at least not ones from after 1990, and … shit, we can't use IMDB, or printouts from websites that might list actors. I don't know if that would twig it, but --

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: Movies?

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: asked Amaryllis, suddenly confused.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: The name,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I said.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: It belongs to an actor from Earth.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: What.

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: Amaryllis was staring at me.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: He was a child actor, became a movie star, now … kind of a meme, I guess,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I said.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: Juniper, you confirmed that there weren't infohazards on Earth,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Amaryllis.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: No,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I said.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: A meme, just … not making fun of him, exactly, because he invited a lot of it on himself, and I think he knew what he was doing, but the idea of him was bigger than the reality? And there was this video,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: Actual Cannibal Shia LaBeouf,

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: which I guess I can't say the name of, but the joke was that he was a kind of weird Hollywood actor being portrayed as a horror movie monster. It wasn't horrifying, really, it was the juxtaposition. It was a joke. And then someone made it into a rules-light game that you could play with no prep and sixty seconds to make characters.

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I paused.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: We only played it two or three times, it was supposed to be campy, not …

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I trailed off.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: I had no idea he existed on Aerb. You're not supposed to be able to summon him, not in the base rules, that was just something Arthur came up with, an improvisation. I mean, one that fit well within the theme of the game, but still.

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: Amaryllis was staring at me. I could see disgust on her face, but I was pretty sure that it was aimed at the world of Aerb, rather than at me personally.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: Look,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I said.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: It's fine. We're past the moment of danger, right?

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: Maybe,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Amaryllis.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: Probably.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: And now that I know, I can avoid it,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I said.

content.speaker: Fenn
content.text: You could have told us beforehand,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Fenn. This was directed at Amaryllis, not me.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: Oh, yes,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Amaryllis.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: That's a fucking brilliant idea, spreading knowledge of things that are dangerous to know and even more dangerous to say, and which might literally kill me if spoken by someone else. Why did I not think to tell you, of all people?

content.speaker: Fenn
content.text: I love when you get snarky,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Fenn with a grin.

content.speaker: Fenn
content.text: So are we going to play a game of Actual Cannibal --

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: Valencia moved over to Fenn in the space of a heartbeat, grabbing her wrist and thrusting it up and behind her back, forcing her down onto the table. Valencia's hand covered Fenn's mouth in the same motion. Fenn stayed down, not trying to fight it. After a few seconds, muffled words came from behind Valencia's hand.

content.speaker: Valencia
content.text: She's licking me,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Valencia.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: I think she was probably making a joke,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I said.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: She wasn't actually going to say it.

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: There was more muffled noise from Fenn.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: Not a thing that anyone should joke about,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Amaryllis.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: It's a word -- name that's killed thousands.

content.speaker: Grak
content.text: How many of those because you tried to weaponize it?

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text:
asked Grak.

Amaryllis' lips went thin.

content.speaker: Valencia
content.text: I'm going to let her up now,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Valencia. Her eyes had an alertness to them that I was growing better at recognizing, which was a clear sign that she was, temporarily, something more than just herself. It was trivial for her to mask, when she had a devil, but less so when she had a demon, and much of the time she didn't bother.

content.speaker: Fenn
content.text: I obviously wasn't going to say it,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Fenn and she sat up in her chair.

content.speaker: Fenn
content.text: If we can't joke about things trying to kill us, what can we joke about?

content.speaker: Grak
content.text: Puns,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text:
said Grak.

Amaryllis stood up from her chair.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: I think I'm done for the day,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: she said.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: I'll be in the study if anyone needs me.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: I think I'm done too, sorry,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I said.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: That was, uh, sort of an unpleasant reminder of what kind of world this is.

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text:
Fenn grumped at that, but didn't gainsay me. When I left, she was already back into animated conversation with the others. I had sort of thought that with Amaryllis and I gone, the common room might empty, but there were apparently things they wanted to talk with each other about. Personally, I wanted to be alone.

Fenn and I shared a bedroom on the third floor, up the house's grand central staircase and with a view of the cold, grey, bleak Isle of Poran. The ceilings were high throughout the house, which in the case of our bedroom allowed for an enormous four-poster bed for Fenn and I, which we could draw the curtains on for privacy. We had dressers filled with clothes, half from Earth and half from Aerb, and a fireplace with a pair of armchairs in front of it. We barely ever used the fireplace; Bethel had generated a number of Earth books on architecture and building practices, which had led her to discover central heating, and that was more or less the end of fireplaces being needed for anything aside from atmosphere.

I did light the fireplace when I came back to our room though, because I was in need of some atmosphere as a backdrop for my thoughts.

There was a knock on my door before I could get too lost in thinking.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: Come in,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text:
I said.

Amaryllis slipped in and shut the door behind her, quickly taking the seat beside me. She looked at the fire and stayed silent for a while.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: Just wanted company?

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I asked.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: No,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: she said, after some time had passed.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: I think what just happened was a warning.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: Maybe,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I said.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: A warning from the Dungeon Master that if we sit around doing nothing, adventure will come to us?

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: I don't know,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Amaryllis. The armchair was big, and made her look smaller than she was.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: Something like that.

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: She turned to me.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: I know you don't want to level up again. It's something we should talk about more. You didn't tell me how bad it was the time before, when it was just you and Fenn. You had two and a half months and you just ignored it, like it was going to go away on its own. I should have asked, but I just … I thought you had it under control.

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I shifted in my seat.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: I don't understand the point of the pleasure,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I said.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: If you were an idiot, you'd think that it was a good way to compel me to go adventuring more, to complete quests, to kill things … but I was given the resources to alter myself early on, and if you were literally omniscient, then you'd have to understand that I would be horrified by the idea of losing myself to an impulse to become stronger. Right? I've got a disincentive to pursue leveling up now.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: It's terrible game design,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Amaryllis.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: But we need you to level up.

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I turned to look at her.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: There are things that only I can do,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: I said.

content.speaker: Juniper
content.text: I know. I don't want to lose myself though. I don't want my identity to be stripped away, not more than it already has been. The levels have been getting further apart, but they're ramping up in intensity. If you hadn't been there ...

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: I know,

content.speaker: NARRATOR
content.text: said Amaryllis. Her voice was soft.

content.speaker: Amaryllis
content.text: You want to refuse the call.
